results.title: Work Policies May Be Kinder, but Brutal Competition Isn’t
results.summary: Top-tier employers may be changing their official policies in a nod to work-life balance, but brutal competition remains an inescapable component of workers’ daily lives.

results.title: Depiction of Amazon Stirs a Debate About Work Culture
results.summary: Details of working conditions at Amazon led to a response from employees, relatives and friends.

multimedia.caption: Amazon is building new offices in Seattle and, in about three years, will have enough space for about 50,000 employees.

results.title: Jeff Bezos and Amazon Employees Join Debate Over Its Culture
results.summary: The company’s chief told employees that he didn’t recognize the “soulless, dystopian workplace” that he said was depicted in a New York Times article.
results.byline: By DAVID STREITFELD and JODI KANTOR

multimedia.caption: Jeff Bezos, chief executive of Amazon, encouraged employees to report “callous” management practices.
Jeff Bezos, chief executive of Amazon, encouraged employees to report “callous” management practices.
Jeff Bezos, chief executive of Amazon, encouraged employees to report “callous” management practices.

results.title: Inside Amazon: Wrestling Big Ideas in a Bruising Workplace
results.summary: The company is conducting an experiment in how far it can push white-collar workers to get them to achieve its ever-expanding ambitions.
results.byline: By JODI KANTOR and DAVID STREITFELD

multimedia.caption: Amazon employees on a lunch break. Many employees say they spend hours working at home most nights or on weekends.

results.title: Data-Crunching Is Coming to Help Your Boss Manage Your Time
results.summary: Employers of all types are using a wide range of technological tools to monitor workers’ efforts and motivate them.

multimedia.caption: Myrna Arias, a saleswoman for Intermex, a money-transfer company, has claimed in a lawsuit that she was required to download an app on her cellphone that tracked her whereabouts 24 hours a day.

results.title: Amazon’s Workplace Culture Continues to Spur Online Debates
results.summary: The online argument over Amazon’s white-collar workplace gathered steam as employees and ex-employees recounted their own experiences at the retailer.

results.title: Peach, a Lunch Delivery Service, Plans Expansion
results.summary: Peach, which has secured a $8 million investment, uses a somewhat different model than PostMates and GrubHub.

results.title: U.S. Transfer of Internet Oversight Is Delayed
results.summary: The Commerce Department said it would delay by at least a year its plan to cede authority over the global address system for the web.

results.title: Accomable: Lessons From an Inspiring Start-Up
results.summary: A new start-up Accomable seeks to be the “Airbnb for disabled people and anyone with mobility difficulties.”

multimedia.caption: Srin Madipalli at Sandy Neck Beach on Cape Cod. Mr. Madipalli, who has spinal muscular atrophy, co-founded Accomable, which he described as an Airbnb for those with mobility problems.

results.title: Where to See the Inequality Gap Wrought by the Tech Boom
results.summary: Perhaps nowhere is the inequality gap created by the latest technology boom as evident as in San Francisco’s Tenderloin neighborhood, a longtime low-income area that is now increasingly populated by tech start-ups.

results.title: Blending Tech Workers and Locals in San Francisco’s Troubled Mid-Market
results.summary: Tech giants like Twitter and Spotify have descended on one of the poorest neighborhoods in the Bay Area, bringing prosperity for some and upheaval for others.

multimedia.caption: Some of the Tenderloin’s longtime residents are learning newfound wealth for some does not mean newfound prosperity — or even livability — for everyone.
Some of the Tenderloin’s longtime residents are learning newfound wealth for some does not mean newfound prosperity — or even livability — for everyone.

results.title: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Google and Tinder Shake Up the Internet
results.summary: Google reorganized under a new name, Alphabet, and Tinder blew up on Twitter in response to an article in Vanity Fair.
results.byline: By FARHAD MANJOO and MIKE ISAAC

multimedia.caption: Tinder is, in some ways, simply another marketplace facilitated by the Internet, just as we’ve had the eBays and Craigslists of the world.

results.title: Google Stays in the News With Chromebooks and Antitrust Issues
results.summary: Google unveiled a new version of its Chrome operating system, along with Chromebook computing devices made by Dell. It’s been busy week for the company that’s reinventing itself as Alphabet while dealing with antitrust concerns in Europe.

results.title: A Conversation With Glenn Lurie, Chief of AT&T Mobility
results.summary: AT&T’s chief of mobile, Glenn Lurie, discusses easy-to-understand phone plans and the company’s acquisition of DirecTV.

multimedia.caption: Glen Lurie helped negotiate the deal that temporarily brought Apple’s first iPhone exclusively to AT&T.

results.title: Google Unveils New Chrome Operating System for Business Customers
results.summary: Google and Dell show off the next version of Chromebooks. They look nice, but what really matters is changes in the back end to get older applications online.

results.title: New School Technology for Class and the Quad
results.summary: New devices include some to help students with note-taking, navigating a laptop and data storage. But first, there’s a way to dispose of old gadgets.

results.title: Video Feature: Inexpensive Apps for Entrepreneurs and Start-Ups
results.summary: These digital tools — many of which are free — can improve efficiency by helping your team perform a variety of functions, like filing expense reports, designing logos and enacting ideas.

results.title: Nebia, a Shower Head Start-Up, Receives Funding From Timothy Cook of Apple
results.summary: Nebia, a start-up that has developed a water-conserving shower head, already has funding from Silicon Valley’s top brass, including Apple chief executive Timothy D. Cook.

multimedia.caption: Nebia has tested prototypes of its shower head on the campuses of Apple, Google and Stanford University.

results.title: Stopping the iPhone Step Counter
results.summary: Turning off the default motion tracking function, defending against PC scams and requesting order history reports from Amazon.

results.title: Helix, a New Gene Sequencing Venture, Aims to Create Digital Hub for Genomics
results.summary: Illumina and two investment firms are spending $100 million on Helix, which has been in the works for more than a year.
results.byline: By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

results.title: Amazon Chief’s Message to Employees
results.summary: In an email to all Amazon employees, Jeff Bezos wrote, “The article doesn’t describe the Amazon I know or the caring Amazonians I work with every day.”

results.title: Why Amazon May Take a Page From Walmart’s Labor Playbook
results.summary: The perception of Amazon as a difficult place to work could force the online retailer to initiate reforms, as Walmart has done with its own billion-dollar program.

results.title: Hacking Case Raises Question on Securities Fraud
results.summary: Stealing corporate information from computers to make trades certainly looks like insider trading, but it can depend on court jurisdiction.

results.title: Scaling China’s Great Firewall
results.summary: The government hopes to foster an Internet society that doesn't concern itself with politics or current affairs.
